Got all the work you can handle if you're interested. SAM
I'm interested... Sam, seizing an opportunity here. 22 SAM (CONT'D)
But I'm puttin my own crew together. We go 50/50 on the jobs. You cover any heavy machines I need. CONTRACTOR
60/40 til you pay me back on the tools. Then we'll go half. SAM
You got a deal. CUT TO:
A SHOT of Lynn carefully applying a vinyl application on a new (but used) truck that reads, "Childers Construction CUT TO:
C.U. ON lynn's closed eyes -- smiling -- LYNN
What are you doin, Sam Childers? Months later and we're with Lynn and Paige, their eyes sh leads them both by the hand... PAIGE
I wanna peek. SAM
Keep em closed. Sam finally stops them. SAM (CONT'D)
Ok. Open em up. They do and both of their eyes go wide with surprise. PAIGE
Where are we? SAM
We're home, little girl. REVERSE to see a modest two bedroom house at the end of t driveway. Their new home. PAIGE
That's ours? 23 SAM
Sure is. Go check it out. Paige sprints for the house as Lynn hugs Sam, softly star into his shoulder. LYNN
It's beautiful.
The first night in their new home and we see a few unpack boxes here.
Paige sound asleep on a small bed upstairs.
Lynn in the kitchen organizing the cabinets. And Sam ente a box, sets it on the counter. SAM
That's everything. LYNN
You get what's in the trunk? SAM
Yep. Lynn looking up, seeing how dirty Sam is from the move... LYNN
Lord, you're filthy, Sam Childers. Lynn tossing him a kitchen towel. Sam, smiling mischievou SAM
Who you callin filthy, woman? LYNN
You. SAM
You dirtier than I am. LYNN
No I ain't. SAM
Yes you are. I seen it. C'mon, girl, gimme a little shake... 24
Sam winking at her and playfully snapping a kitchen towel butt... Lynn giggling and scooting away... LYNN
I ain't doin that no more. SAM
... just a little somethin for yer old man, c'mon... And he snaps her butt again but she grabs the towel and s back... SAM (CONT'D)
Owww! LYNN
You gimme a little shake... She snaps him again and he feels the sting... SAM

C'mon, Lynn... She snaps him again but he grabs her and they fall into e against the counter... laughing... and he kisses her... p first and then it becomes more passionate... and just as to lead somewhere we go...
Two years later and we're watching a congregation finish hymn. Sam, Lynn, Daisy, and Paige (10) in the crowd liste Pastor Krause. PASTOR KRAUSE

Today we are blessed with a special guest. It's my pleasure to welcome Pastor Relling from the Kilangire Christian Ministry in Uganda, Africa. Pastor... Polite applause as a tall, white South African man named RELLING steps up to the pulpit, and in a deep Afrikaner a BEGINS -- RELLING
Thank you Pastor Krause, and thank you brothers and sisters for inviting me into this house of the Lord. (BEAT)

I'm here today to talk to you about your Christian brothers and sisters, families just like yours, a half a world away that desperately need your help... And we see Sam in this sea of faces, listening. 25

Parishioners slowly filing out of the church after servic Paige, and a few other women chatting by the entrance. And now Lynn looks over her shoulder and sees Sam talking Relling off to the side, just the two of them in a corner discussion.

The first thing we notice is the relative "opulence" of t place... deep shag, new color TV, matching sectional sofa rural idea of making it. Sam, Lynn, Daisy and Paige at th table eating. Sam in his own world, oblivious to the MINO CONVERSATION until -- LYNN
Paige, go get some more beans. Paige heads to the kitchen. LYNN (CONT'D)
What are you thinking? SAM
Thinking about Africa. Paige comes back in carrying the beans. PAIGE
They have tigers over there? SAM (JOKINGLY)
They eat people! LYNN
What about Africa? SAM
Just thinkin bout that fella today. PAIGE
He talked funny. LYNN
Just from a different place than us, baby, that's all. SAM
Was thinkin maybe I'd go over there. Help em out fer a few weeks. 26 DAISY
Africa? PAIGE
To see the tigers. SAM
He was talkin about puttin box beam roofs on school houses over there. LYNN
What about finishing that job in Boswell? SAM
I'll only be gone a few weeks. Be back before you know it.

Two weeks later and we're in the rural countryside outsid Uganda. Sam on the roof of a bombed out school building w white VOLUNTEERS, working. Sam looks below to see a dozen black men dressed in the r fatigues of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA). carrying an AK 47 and standing guard at various points ar compound. The lead soldier is a man named DENG. ANGLE thr we'll come to know as "NINETEEN", "MARCO" and "A.J."
It's later and we see Deng sitting underneath an awning b working on his machine gun. Sam approaches... SAM
You Ugandan Army or what? DENG
SAM
What's that? DENG
Sudanese People's Liberation Army. We are freedom fighters. SAM
Name's Sam Childers. DENG
I am Deng. There is a certain reserved nobility in this man, in the carries himself and speaks. An unwavering strength and se born from a lifetime of war and struggle. 27 SAM
(re: Deng's weapon) Givin ya problems? DENG
Yes. A bit. SAM
Double-feed? DENG
Sometimes. SAM
Lemme have a look... Deng hesitates, then hands his AK over to Sam who pops th and studies it... SAM (CONT'D)
Yer mag is tight. See here... (INDICATING)
The loads are feedin right to the barrel face. That's yer problem... Sam pulls out a knife and begins to work on the base plat mag as he explains... SAM (CONT'D)
... you need this plate to ramp into the chamber... that way yer brass won't get stuck... (FINISHING)
... there ya go, should be better... And Sam hands the weapon back. DENG
Thank you. SAM
No problem. DENG
Are you military? SAM
No, not me. I ain't the military type. Ain't so good with bein told what to do. DENG
When did you learn about weapons? Sam considers the question for a moment... then simply sa 28 SAM
Long time ago. Different life.
Fifteen or twenty volunteers lounging on cots in this dor cards, talking, smoking. And we find Sam off from the gro bunk, reading The Bible...
Hey Childers... Sam turns to find a British man in his late 20's named DA next to him, thick Cockney accent, smoking a cigarette. DAN
Some of us are going into Kampala tomorrow night. Find ourselves a little fun this weekend. You in? SAM
I was thinkin bout goin up north. DAN
You crazy? There's a civil war going on up there. SAM
I know.
It's mid-day, blazing hot, and we see Sam approaching Den SAM
Hey, Deng, you wanna Coke? Sam offers him a can and he takes it. DENG
Thank you. SAM
Got a question for ya. DENG
Yes? SAM
I wanna go into Sudan this weekend. Need someone to show me around. You interested? DENG
The others are going into Kampala. 29 SAM
That ain't my speed no more. I wanna see some country. Deng looks at him, surprised by the request... DENG
You want to see?

A dirt road cutting through grassy plain stretching in ev direction... and we see a BRIGHT YELLOW BUS speeding towa the distance, kicking a rooster tail of dust high into th and as it gets closer we see 15 or 20 men piled onto the hanging on for dear life as this bus bounces over the roa
... Sam and Deng crammed into this crowded bus... SAM
They always drive this fast? DENG

Traveling is the most dangerous time in Sudan. If the rebels find you on the open road it would be very bad. An awkward silence as Deng stares out the window. Sam wan connect here, but Deng is reticent. SAM
You got kids, Deng? DENG
No. I have no children. SAM
Where you from? DENG
A little village called Aweil. Many hours from here. SAM
That's where your family is? And Deng simply says... DENG
My family was killed by LRA. (BEAT)
Unyama is about two hours from here. We will stop there for lunch. 30
Deng turns and looks out the window again, silent, quietl the land blur past. And Sam says nothing more, intuitivel this man's need to be alone in the moment. A great, lost

A dense sea of people. 20,000 displaced refugees living o each other. Life is lived out in the open here... women bent over bri colored washtubs sloshing clothes in soapy water... smoke cooking pots drifting into the air... semi-clothed childr with even younger children on their hips, running everywh poverty and hopelessness is overwhelming. And we see Sam and Deng walking through the camp... DENG
The Muslim North has tried to kill the Christian South for 30 years. Two million have lost their lives... Deng sweeping his hand, indicating the mass of refugees. DENG (CONT'D)
... these people have been driven from their villages, however these camps are not much better...

A row of wood sheds and worn nylon tents marks the hospit Each enclosure jammed with the desperately sick. Battle-w WORKERS move among them, doing what they can, caring for who are most desperately ill. DENG

Cholera and Malaria are everywhere, there is little food and not enough UN soldiers to protect everyone. Even here they worry the LRA will attack at night. And another SPLA soldier comes up to Deng -- SPLA SOLDIER 1 (ARABIC)
Are you from Kitgum? DENG (ARABIC)
Yes. SPLA SOLDIER 1 (ARABIC)
Someone wants to speak with you. 31
Deng turns to Sam... DENG
I'm sorry, Sam... I'll be five minutes. SAM

Course, do what you gotta do. Deng leaves and now Sam is completely alone, taking in th humanity all around him. And suddenly there's COMMOTION! workers coming into this tent carrying a WOMAN on a stret of the aid workers looking around -- a white woman -- mid her name is AGNETE CLOSSON, Regional Director of Doctors Borders. She sees Sam across the tent. AGNETE
Excuse me. You. Can you help please? Sam moving to her -- AGNETE (CONT'D)
We need to transfer her to the bed. Get her shoulders... Sam grabbing the woman underneath the shoulders as anothe worker gets her feet... AGNETE (CONT'D)

One, two, three... And they swing the woman over to a cot... but as they do piece of blood-stained muslin that was covering her face away... and we see that she has been mutilated... her lip of her face... ... and now a DOCTOR sweeps into the tent and begins to w Sam and Agnete pushed back, away from the action. Sam sti by what he's seen. SAM
What happened to her face? AGNETE
The rebels cut off her lips because she argued. These are Kony's orders. SAM
Who's Kony? Agnete, suddenly suspicious, takes an appraising look of AGNETE
Who are you with? SAM
I'm with Deng over there. 32 AGNETE
What organization are you with? SAM
Working with a Christian group down South. Just up here takin a look around, seein a bit of the country. AGNETE
This isn't a tourist destination, this is a war zone. You stay in this area, you'll be killed. (BEAT)
Thank you for your help. And she walks off.

Establishing a bustling trading center on the border of U Sudan. Noisy and overpopulated, a maze of concrete and ti buildings, hundreds of people on the streets, riding bicy finishing their business before nightfall.

A stale room with two cots, bare, institutional. Deng on his cot, pulling off his boots, taking off his jacket, ge comfortable. And we see Sam sitting on a small balcony ov the empty street below. DENG
Some say Joseph Kony is a wizard. A shapeshifter. He calls himself a Christian... He pulls a baggy of tobacco from his pocket and begins to cigarette... DENG (CONT'D)
... but I say he is Satan, who devours his own people. SAM
Kony is the leader of the LRA? DENG

He is the one we have been fighting for years. But there is very little we can do. Our weapons are old, and our boots are full of holes. We have been forgotten by the rest of the world. And now Deng turns to Sam... 33 DENG (CONT'D)
Why are you here? SAM
S'cuse me? DENG
What are you looking for in this place? SAM
Ain't lookin for nuthin. Deng staring at him, skeptical... DENG
And then you will get your picture and go back to your life and all this will just be a story you tell your friends.

Sam has no response... and Deng lights his cigarette... a we hear voices... through the open window... children's v Sam peering into the darkness but seeing nothing... only streets... and then one-by-one... out of the darkness lik apparitions... we see children coming up the street carry bedrolls... some of them singing spiritual hymns as they laughing as children do... at first just a dozen or so... more... fifty... a hundred...
Deng steps onto the balcony next to Sam. DENG
They are night commuters. They come from deep in the bush. Their parents send them out because it is safer to sleep here than in their own homes. SAM
Why? DENG

Because death comes at night in the villages and refugee camps. And we continue to watch this great migration of children streaming into this town... a few of them finding a dark below us... unrolling their reed mats... huddling up agai other for the long night... DENG (CONT'D)
These are the lucky one so far. The ones the rebels have not found. The invisible children. 34
Sam watching them for another beat then suddenly turning, back into the room... DENG (CONT'D)
Where are you going?
Sam coming down these steps. Deng following. DENG (CALLING AFTER)
Sam...
Sam exiting the hotel, moving to a group of 5 children hu the sidewalk... SAM
Get up... let's go... The children looking up, surprised to see a white man her SAM (CONT'D)
Come on... The children getting to their feet... and Sam moves to an cluster of children up the block as Deng catches up to hi DENG
What are you doing? SAM

They ain't sleepin out here. Tell em they're comin inside. (to children on the ground) Ya'll get up... let's go... And Sam starts to move up the block further, wanting to g more children, but Deng stops him... DENG
Sam, there are too many... And he looks up the street and we see more children here thought... hundreds of young kids huddled on the streets. DENG (CONT'D)
... you can't help them all. Sam knows he's right. A moment here as he looks to the ch gathered, staring up at him... SAM
I can help these here. 35
-- and a DOZEN CHILDREN are ushered into this small room. pushing their cots against a wall so there's more space. speaking to the children -- DENG (ARABIC)

Settle down... it's alright... you can sleep here till morning... -- and they begin to settle onto the floor... and now we particular BOY in this group... maybe 8 years old... wear GREEN SHORTS... and we watch as he and his SISTER move to of the room and unroll their mats... ... and eventually Sam turns off the lamp and we stay her dark... Sam on his cot, listening to these 12 little chil breathing... their shifting bodies on the floor trying to comfortable... and then... CUT TO:
Sam's closed eyes... sound asleep... Just before dawn. Deng standing over him, shaking him awa DENG
The LRA attacked a village last night. Sam looking up to him... DENG (CONT'D)
You said you wanted to see. Sam sits up, looks around the hotel room and we see that empty... the children vanished... only a small, handmade ground which has been left behind.

Sam, Deng, and a few other SPLA SOLDIERS jammed into the this truck, carrying heavy weapons, bouncing fast over th dirt road... featureless savanna FADING into sporadic mud the outskirts of a VILLAGE in the distance... and thin co black smoke twisting into the air... ... and as the truck gets closer to the village we begin CHILDREN walking along the side of the road... night comm returning to their village... some of them huddled togeth weeping... 36
... and we notice -- Sam notices -- the little boy in the SHORTS, walking hand-in-hand with his sister, their faces masks of fear as they move closer to their home.

The pickup arrives and Sam, Deng, and the other soldiers and this is what they see: Complete devastation. 30 or 40 bodies mutilated and stack smoking tukuls. Some children already here, on their knee next to the corpses of their parents. If you could smell would smell of burnt flesh and death. Sam silent, aghast, just staring at the horror all around ... and now we see GREEN SHORTS and his sister arriving a village... moving to their family's tukul and discovering mother and father piled outside. Naked and burned alive. sister falls onto her mother's corpse and begins to wail SHORTS stands there -- frozen -- staring down at his dead and suddenly -- MOVEMENT! -- from inside the tukul... a small dog... a fa darting into the open... running across the dirt... GREEN going after it, yelling his name... Sam watching the boy chasing after his dog, rounding a co sight... ... for a moment... ... just the boy's voice calling after his dog... and the
A muffled burst -- in the distance -- Sam, Deng, and the soldiers running out of the village toward the explosion.

... Sam, Deng, and the others arriving at the source of t explosion. And we see GREEN SHORTS laying on the side of cut in half by a land mine... his dead eyes wide open wit surprise... ... and Sam drops to his knees... lifting what's left of into his arms and rocking him back and forth... and we wa terrible sadness overtakes him... something happening her fierce and overwhelming burden dropping into this man as this dead boy... in the dirt... in the middle of this sav world... ... and as Sam puts it, his "life changed forever" in thi and we see him looking up to the heavens... 37
tears streaming down his face... saying something we can' it's a promise... to God... To save the children of Sudan.

A bright, fluorescent corridor filled with garish adverti harried travelers rushing to make planes... and we find S down this concourse, carrying his duffle bag, his face expressionless. He reaches a revolving door but stops... pass through... sees Lynn, Paige, and his mother waiting the other side... their happy, expectant faces... But they don't see him yet... and he just stays here... h watching them through the glass... and as Sam puts it, at moment he realized he would never look at his own family way again... in some way lost to them forever after what the side of road in Yei... ... and finally he forces a smile, pushes through the rev and we watch, from this side of the glass, as Paige leaps arms... Lynn and Daisy moving to him too, embracing him, him home.
Paige brushing her teeth at the sink. Sam watching her fr doorway... PAIGE
You see any tigers over there? SAM
Naw, didn't see no tigers. PAIGE
But they do have them over in Africa. SAM
So I hear, but not where I was. PAIGE
Sure am glad you're home. SAM
Me too, bug. PAIGE
I'm thinkin of a plane... SAM
It's late, you better get to bed... And he grabs her and carries her into the bedroom, plops the bed... 38 PAIGE
C'mon, plane... I'm thinkin of a plane... Sam giving in, playing their little game as she gets unde covers... SAM
You said plane, I'm thinkin of a train... PAIGE
You said train, I'm thinkin of a brain. SAM
You said brain, I'm thinkin of a... (HESITATING) PAIGE
Gotcha! SAM
Ok, you got me. PAIGE
You coulda said drain, or mane... like horse's hair. Sam bending over, kissing her forehead... SAM
Sweet dreams, bug.
Sam coming out of Paige's bedroom, pulling the door close Lynn waiting for him. LYNN
You comin to bed? SAM
In a bit LYNN
You ok? SAM
Just a long flight. She senses more but knows this man well enough not to pus she simply turns away.
Quiet. Just Sam on this porch all alone, been here for so eyes far off, images in his mind he can't seem to shake. 39

And he steps into the yard... walking along the side of t just moving... trying to shed this feeling like snakeskin ... and he comes to something on the ground which stops h his tracks... something we don't see yet... and slowly he down and picks up... A LITTLE DOLL. One of Paige's toys. Soiled and faded and dirt. And we watch him holding this forgotten doll... and see on his face ain't pretty... his world collapsing out him... trying to keep rein on his emotions... a battle he
Lynn stirs awake, looks next to her and realizes Sam neve to bed the night before.
Lynn coming out the front door in her nightgown, sees a l a utility shed in the back...
... Lynn slowly pushing open the door to find Sam on the hunched over a pad of Paige's art paper... drawing... pap strewn all around him... been here all night... LYNN
Baby, whatcha doin? He looks up... SAM
Makin plans. LYNN
You been to bed yet? He gathers up a couple of the papers, moves to her. SAM
I had a vision last night, Lynn. Crazy as it sounds, God spoke to me... He hands her a sheet of paper -- CU to see it's a crude d building. SAM (CONT'D)
I'm gonna build a church. LYNN
A church? 40 SAM

Right across the street. Not like Faith United or Calvary Fellowship. Place that ain't gonna turn you away if you a drug addict or a prostitute or whatever. Place for sinners, just like me, who wanna hear the word of God. Lynn studying him, trying to judge how serious he is here looking back at her, his eyes like we haven't seen them b Sparkling. LYNN
How we gonna pay for a church, Sam? SAM
We got money in the bank. Business is good. Besides, I own a construction company... (SMILING)
I'm gonna give us one heck of a good deal on the build. She smiles, shaking her head, catching his enthusiasm... LYNN
Yer crazy. SAM
`Lil bit. LYNN
What's that? He hands her the other paper -- CU to see it's a another SAM
That's the orphanage I wanna build. In Sudan. CUT TO:

Eight months later and we're looking at a simple, cinder church which is under construction. A scattering of picku parked at the site and a flurry of activity. WORKMEN pour laying sheetrock, etc. And Sam in the middle of this crew the finishing touches on a timber frame which is about to
Children at play, laughing, screaming, swinging on swing digging in a sand pit. And we see Sam off to the side, le against a (new) black Harley, watching Paige playing in t 41
Sam Childers... Sam turns to see a BIKER, late 40's, leather vest, standi 12 year old DAUGHTER. SAM
That's me. The Biker extends his hand, they shake. BIKER
Hey bro, Ben Hobbes, knew each other long time ago. SAM
Yeah, Ben, how you doin? DAUGHTER
Daddy, I'm gonna go. BIKER
OK, sweetie... She runs off. BIKER (CONT'D)
Goddamn, they grow up quick, don't they? SAM
Sure do. BIKER
Hey, nuthin fer nuthin, Sam, but rumor has it you was puttin up a chapel over there in Central City. SAM
That's right. Gonna minister to anybody who's lookin for The Lord. BIKER
That's good, man. Maybe you can do somethin bout your old friend, Donnie. SAM
What about em? BIKER
He ain't doin so good, bro. But hey, good seein ya' man. 42

A torn up house in a shitty part of town, windows spray p black. Sam pulls up to the curb on his Harley, gets off, of the bike's hard cases and pulls out the same SAWED OFF we've seen before... chambers a slug as he moves toward t
Dark, junkie squalor. Two or three people slumped on a ra strung-out, watching a flickering TV -- and then --
Sam coming into the house -- sawed-off leveled -- junkies for cover -- YELLING! -- CHAOS! -- Sam moving into --

Sam comes around the corner and finds himself face-to-fac CRACKHEAD pointing a .357 MAGNUM -- eyes amped up and wil shaking -- a stand-off -- and Sam sees a body on a bare m the b.g. -- bone thin and pale -- spent hypodermic hangin his arm -- It's Donnie. SAM
I'm here for that boy right there. You gonna get in the way a that? A TENSE BEAT -- not sure how this is gonna go -- and then CRACKHEAD shakes his head "no"

Donnie in a bed, covers pulled up to his neck and he's sh retching in a bucket, deep in the throes of a detox. Sam here doing what they can, toweling off his forehead, tryi him warm, as Donnie pulls the sheets tighter, gritting hi shaking his head. DONNIE
I can't do this. SAM
Look at me. God don't make trash, boy. Now he ain't givin up on you, so don't give up on him, you hear me? And somehow Donnie finds strength in his words, and in Sa touching his head, and he nods. 43

A bright Sunday morning and we're staring at the cinder b which is almost completely finished... the sound of a gar coming from inside, playing an unlikely rendition of a sp hymn... and a handful of people, dressed for service, mov cement stairs into...
And we see Donnie, dressed in his biker jacket and a butt shirt, sober for the moment, greeting people as they come the front door. Standing next to him is Daisy handing out DONNIE
Welcome to Shekinah Fellowship Church.

Still under construction. Exposed beams and bare insulati walls. There's a small riser at the front of the hall wit organ, and the GARAGE BAND playing the rocked-out hymn. A handful of people here sitting in pews. FARMERS in clea FACTORY WORKERS, BIKERS still dressed in their riding lea listening to the garage band and chatting. And now we see Lynn and Paige (11) standing near the back nervous, checking her watch.
Sam on his knees, sleeves rolled up to his elbows, wrench leaking pipe. Lynn and Daisy walk in... LYNN
It's five-til and he still ain't here. Sam hearing this, moving to his feet, toweling off his ha SAM
You call him? (LYNN NODS)
Try him again. Lynn exits and Daisy steps forward, shuts the door behind she and Sam here alone now. DAISY
You like this dress, Sam? SAM
What, mom? 44 DAISY
You ain't never seen this one. I bought it a long time ago. Been keepin it for a special occasion. SAM
It's nice. DAISY

I never told you this but when I was pregnant with you, now this was way back, probably 1960, when yer daddy and I was still in Grand Rapids, a Pastor prophesied over me. Pulled me right up on stage and laid his hands on my belly and told me I was gonna have a Preacher for a son. (smiling at the thought) Yer daddy and I were so proud. I remember we went home and neither of us could sleep all night. Just laid there and talked bout you, bout what was comin. SAM
I just built a church. I ain't no preacher. DAISY
Yes you are. You were born to it. Just took you a little ways to get here.

Sam entering at the back of the chapel, taking a moment t appreciate what he's looking at: 20 or 30 people here in that he built. A dream realized. And he walks down the ce shaking hands with a few people, climbing steps to the al switching on the microphone... SAM
(to the band) Thank you, Tommy. You boys is soundin pretty good up here. Sam turning to the crowd, clearing his throat, clearly ne SAM (CONT'D)
I wanna thank ya'll for comin out for the first day of worship here at Shekinah Fellowship Church. Some applause. Lynn and Paige sitting with Daisy who is b 45 SAM (CONT'D)
The guest preacher we had booked today ain't shown up... so I thought I'd say a word or two. An awkward beat... SAM (CONT'D)
Lotta yous been wonderin what made me wanna build this here church. Seein as I ain't the best seed in the bunch I can understand that. A beat, considering what to say... and he begins... SAM (CONT'D)

Buncha years ago I was runnin from some bad fellas in the woods over there by Cleary. Those old boys was comin after me hard and I reached in my bag lookin for my old shotgun but it was gone. My momma had took it out when I wasn't lookin and put this bible in there instead... Sam holding up a worn bible, and we start to notice somet here... a transformation happening in this man as he spea people. His nervousness falling away and a natural charis over... SAM (CONT'D)

Well I figured I was done for, so I sat down under an old tree with this useless book and I waited... And we see the congregation hanging on his every word, id with this man standing before them. One of their own. SAM (CONT'D)

... and then the strangest thing happened. Them boys ran right on past me. Didn't even see me sittin there. Now the way I figure it, things would have turned out pretty different if I had pulled out that shotgun instead of this here Bible. And that's probably the first time I can remember God savin my butt. (BEAT)
God... and my momma. Some laughter and applause... SAM (CONT'D)
Figure least I could do was build em both this church. And the congregation responds with a Hallelujah! 46
Sam holding Paige, her face buried in his shoulder, cryin SAM
Be back soon as I can. PAIGE
You're gonna miss my play. SAM
Have momma videotape it for me, k? Now I gotta git. Lynn pulling Paige off, kissing Sam on the lips. LYNN
Call us when you can. SAM
I will. Sam turning to Donnie, and we see he's back to the hulkin once was. SAM (CONT'D)
You watch out for em while I'm gone, ya hear? DONNIE
That's done, buddy. Sam winks, slaps Donnie on the shoulder, as we -- CUT TO:
And we see a line of SPLA soldiers (including NINETEEN, M A.J.) sitting in the dirt, pulling on NEW BOOTS, smiling, polishing them to a high shine. Sam and Deng watching the soldiers. DENG
You came all this way to bring us new boots?
Deng driving fast down this bumpy road. Sam in the passen Nineteen, Marco, and A.J. in the flatbed of this truck, e watchful. 47 SAM
Right here, stop the truck!
Sam already out of the truck, moving into the bush. Deng following... DENG
Sam, wait... But he's not listening, moving through the scrub to a sma clearing... walking around... DENG (CONT'D)
It is not safe here. Sam kneeling down, picking up a handful of red dirt, lett trickle through his fingers... SAM
This is it...

location: ON THE BORDER OF SUDAN AND UGANDA

text: Establishing a busy trading town on the border of Sudan a And we see a small crowd of villagers standing underneath watching a small color TV (the only TV for miles) -- on t we see a black man in a military uniform giving a fiery s this is JOHN GARANG -- one of the good guys -- the founde SPLA.

A tight, cramped office filled with villagers. Two or thr here at desks handling the administration of life in the renewing travel papers, registering newborn children, hea complaints from local farmers, etc. And we see Sam and De of these desks, a topographical map splayed out in front ADMINISTRATOR
This is not a good idea. SAM
I think it's a heckuva good idea. ADMINISTRATOR
It would be better further south. Closer to Kampala. SAM
If I wanted to be closer to Kampala, I'd be closer to Kampala. I wanna be right here... Sam pointing to the map. The Administrator turning to Den 48 ADMINISTRATOR (ARABIC)
He should not be this far north. SAM
What are you sayin? ADMINISTRATOR
The villages in this area are very remote, Mr. Childers. There is nothing there. SAM
Then it seems to me them people need help the most. ADMINISTRATOR
(to Deng, Arabic) He will be killed. SAM
Talk to me. The Administrator turning to him, laying it out simply -- ADMINISTRATOR
This is in the war zone, Mr. Childers. The LRA will kill you here. SAM
I don't think you understand me, so lemme make it real clear to ya. I didn't pick this land -- God did.

What we're looking at is the modest beginning of The Ange Africa Children's Orphanage. A cluster of tukuls and 2 or rudimentary wood buildings built on the dirt Sam first le between his fingers. And we see life already finding it's place within these b walls. Acholi WORKERS laying brick on what will eventuall schoolhouse and chapel. And we find Sam with two or three small CHILDREN who are no apparent reason. He's on his knees, trying his best to them but he is way out of his depth here. And now we see Deng in the b.g. approaching with a powerf Ugandan woman in her late 40's. DENG (INTRODUCING)
Sam... this is Betty. She is from the village of Kotido. A few miles from here. 49 SAM
Good to meet you Betty. Betty, no reaction. Just the incessant crying of the chil b.g. DENG
She is knowing that you need someone to run the orphanage. SAM
I'm lookin for somebody who can keep the place in order. Make sure things is taken care of when I'm away. DENG
She can do this. SAM
She's gonna have to take care of the children too, make sure they're fed, fix em when they're sick. Can she do that? Betty hears this, turns to the crying children and softly BETTY (ARABIC)
Quiet now. -- and instantly their crying stops. SAM
Tell her she's hired.
We see Betty and another Camp Woman (ROSE) moving through carrying lanterns, helping the children get ready for sle BETTY (ARABIC)
You two share a blanket and tomorrow we will find another. ROSE (ARABIC)
Shhhh, it's time to shut your eyes... And we see Sam here too, doing what he can, tucking in a kids, starting to make a connection with these children.
And we see a handful of SPLA soldiers stationed around th of the compound, standing guard. Sam and Deng sitting nex lantern by the front gate. 50 SAM
You know what's funny? In English your name means "darn it." DENG
What is this `darn it?' SAM
Deng. It means `shucks.' You know, like you stub your toe and you go "ahhhhh, deng!" Get it? DENG (DEAD SERIOUS)
This is not funny. In my language, in Arabic, names are very important. They tell you everything about a man. (BECOMING HEATED)
Your name proceeds you wherever you go. You are Sam. This is how you are known. In my language this means something. Sam feeling terrible, realizes he's offended him. SAM
I'm sorry, buddy. It was just a joke. Quiet, awkward, just the two of them sitting here quietly beat. Finally... SAM (CONT'D)
What does Sam mean in Arabic? DENG

Small penis. And Deng smiles brightly. Sam realizing he's been played. starts to LAUGH. A deep, guttural, infectious laugh. Sam him, and we sense that at this moment these two have beco And gradually their laughter subsides, and it's quiet aga SAM
Can I ask you a question? DENG
Of course. SAM
You believe in God? Deng considering this for a beat, and then... DENG
I was raised to believe there was a God in heaven. (MORE) 51 DENG (CONT'D)
But it is impossible to live here, to see what I have seen, and not turn your back on him. BEAT. SAM
Maybe you'll invite him in again one day. DENG
I don't think so. CUT TO:
The heavy stillness of an African summer night. Only the Kestrel hawks screeching far off in the distance, hunting and the drone of African Cicadas buzzing all around us.
The children sprawled on their mats sound asleep.
Deng and a few other soldiers sleeping on bedrolls.

Sam sitting on his cot. He rips open an airmail package a out a small VIDEOCASSETTE, slides it in a VIDEOCAMERA, hi ON THE SMALL VIDEO SCREEN we see Paige, dressed in a pilg costume, performing in a Thanksgiving Day play. Her voice through the tiny speakers as she recites her lines. Sam s what he's watching.
A few of the SPLA soldiers sitting next to their weapons dark, smoking, tossing beads into a carved wooden trough, the ancient game of Mancala -- SOLDIER #2 (ARABIC)
That was a mistake... SOLDIER #3 (ARABIC)
Where? SOLDIER #2 (ARABIC)
Right here... your third "house" is open... 52
Soldier #3 reacting to his mistake as --

head_text.subj: -- WE SEE SHADOWS IN THE DARKNESS... MAYBE 10 OR 12 FIGUR
SLOWLY THROUGH THE UNDERBRUSH... LRA REBELS... APPROACHIN

text: The SPLA soldiers oblivious to the advance.
Sam watching Paige's play -- when suddenly -- AN EXPLOSION! -- machinegun fire popping o.s. -- Sam hitt ground, scrambling for cover --
-- Sam rushing out of his tukul -- sees the front gate OB from a grenade blast -- bamboo fence burning -- the death AK47's howling in the darkness -- NEW ANGLE
-- Sam hustling across the compound -- joining Deng and a soldier behind a makeshift shed -- SAM
How many are there? DENG
Two squads... (INDICATING)
There -- and there. Sam peering around the corner -- sees MUZZLE FLASHES in t blackness -- maybe 15 or 20 rebels moving through the bus specters -- flanking the compound -- SAM
Where are your men? DENG
I don't know. Sam looking around, realizing the rest of the SPLA soldie scattered throughout the compound firing randomly into th SAM
They're gonna pick us off like this! Sam, split-second decision here -- and he starts to sprin the compound to -- 53
TERRIFIED SCREAMING! -- the children cowering in the corn Betty and Rose here trying to calm them down -- BETTY (ARABIC)
Stay down! -- stay down! -- ROSE
We are protected! -- Sam bursting through the door -- SAM
-- Betty! Get em to the church right now! (ARABIC)
Quickly. (ENGLISH)
Understand?! -- Betty nodding as Sam rushes out --
-- Sam bombing into this shed -- quickly opening a metal pulling out an AK47 and mags of ammo --
-- Sam scrambling across the compound with the AK -- move Deng and pops a mag into the machinegun -- SAM
Get yer men back to the church! That's our best shot! I'll cover you... And Sam starts to open up the AK -- laying down a curtain suppression fire as Deng shouts to his men -- DENG (ARABIC)
To the church! -- -- and they start to fall back to the center of the orpha

Betty and the other Camp woman herding the terrified chil this building -- the only brick structure on the compound then Deng, Marco, A.J. and the other SPLA soldiers coming moving to the window holes and returning fire -- 54
Sam sweeping the AK back and forth, trying to hold off th long as he can -- and then --
More of the fence eviscerated by a grenade blast.
Sam becoming overwhelmed in the fight -- firing as he ret into the compound --
-- Sam storming into the chapel -- turning to Betty -- SAM
(meaning the children) Put em in the middle! Betty and the other woman do exactly that -- they move th into a tight group in the center of the room. BETTY (ARABIC)
Down here! -- in the center! -- all of you! -- stay down!
Rebels moving through the compound, firing into tukuls an everything on fire.
Sam, Deng and the other soldiers returning fire -- DENG (ARABIC)
Four on the right! NINETEEN (ARABIC)
There are too many! SAM
Just keep firin! Sam starting to open up with his AK -- Krakakakakakak! -- shells showering down around the children huddled in the the room. 55

Rebels swarming around the chapel, but reaching a point w can't advance any further -- -- and we see a rebel squat behind a shed and screw an RP launcher -- he pops up -- levels the launcher at the chap Krakakakakak! He's cut down before he's able to fire --

-- Sam sweeping his AK across the compound -- the other s burning through magazines and reloading -- rebels firing Betty and the children crowded on the floor in the middle STORM OF GUNFIRE -- and we stay in this little chapel -- this last stand -- until we -- CUT TO:

And we see the entire orphanage has been razed to the gro and a few of the children picking through the burned out and torched tukuls, looking for anything salvageable. Den Nineteen, and some of the SPLA soldiers loading the corps rebels into the back of the truck... ... and now we find Sam staring at the brick chapel in th the compound. The only structure that remains. Everything his entire dream -- in ashes.
And we see Lynn pushing a shopping cart down the aisle, p loaded with packaged produce. And we hear BUZZING. Lynn d cell phone out of her purse -- LYNN
Hello?
And we find Sam sitting at a table along this dusty, crow His duffelbag on the ground next to him. SAM (INTO PHONE)
It's me.
Lynn immediately senses something wrong. 56 LYNN
You ok?
And we see that he's not. This man is empty, alone, defea SAM
They burned it to the ground. All of it. Ain't nuthin left.
She hears the anguish in his voice. LYNN
Where are you?
SAM
Nimule...

... I'm comin home. And we're watching her here, clocking the resignation in A moment of quiet for both of them. Lynn sensing the dime his heartache. All she wants to do is bring him home, hol close, ease his pain... but she knows that's not what he not this man...
Sam? SAM
Yeah.
Can you hear me? SAM
I can hear you.
And we see her move around a corner into an empty aisle, the other shoppers. And she says... 57 LYNN
Then quit feelin sorry for yerself. Them children have had their whole lives burned to the ground and worse. How many of them you see givin up?
And we watch Sam listening, finding strength in what this next...
God gave you purpose, Sam Childers. Now stop yer cryin, get off yer butt and build it again.

BEGIN SEQUENCE. Giving us a sense that many months are pa -- Sam and a crew of VILLAGE MEN hauling the charred remn tukuls and burned building out of the compound on their b -- The remainder of the bamboo fence that once surrounded orphanage being torn down. -- Nineteen, Marco, A.J. and a few other SPLA soldiers cu bush away from the edge of the compound with machetes. SAM
Cut it all down... so they got nowhere to hide... -- Sam, Deng and the crew of village men digging post hol the perimeter of the orphanage... VILLAGE MAN 1 (ARABIC)
How far? DENG (ARABIC)

All the way around... -- The men sinking metal beams into the holes with cement surrounding the compound with heavy gage CHAINLINK FENCE. -- New DORMS being built from brick. An INFIRMARY. A MESS SOLDIER'S BARRACKS. And finally, Sam laying the last bric chapel in the center of the compound. Completing it.
A simple administrative office with a short-wave radio an phone. Sam here, sitting at a desk when we hear a knock a 58 SAM
Come on in... The door opens and we see Deng. DENG
Preacher, you need to come see this.

Sam following Deng to the center of the compound where we camp women (including Betty and Rose) dressed in colorful headdresses. Maybe 80 children here, quietly sitting in t watching the women. Nineteen, Marco, A.J. and the rest of soldiers here too, watching from the side. SAM
What's goin on? DENG

The Acholi people were farmers before they were driven from their ancestral homeland. Each year they blessed the soil before a planting. And now the women begin to move in unison... singing an a Acholi song as one of the older orphan boys beats a small accompaniment... DENG (CONT'D) (TRANSLATING)
They are saying that fire brings strength and ashes abundance... The women continuing their dance... moving in a tight cir stomping their feet as they sing... DENG (CONT'D) (TRANSLATING)
... when the land burns, the next year the soil produces more... And now Betty peels away from the group and approaches Sa to him directly in Arabic... BETTY (ARABIC)
The children are your fields... DENG (TRANSLATING)
... she says you are a farmer and these children are your crops... 59
Sam looking to the 80 little orphans watching this from t and now Betty bends down and scoops up a bit of ashen ear her finger across his forehead, blessing him... BETTY (ARABIC)
... and this ground will grow them tall. DENG
... and this ground is richer now and they will grow stronger because of it. OFF SAM standing here with his ashen face, staring at the in front of him -- his African family.

Days later and we see Sam here with Nineteen and a few ot soldiers, eating lunch, trying to learn their language. A humorous to these guys as Sam tries to pronounce some wor Arabic... And suddenly we hear YELLING coming from outside.

Sam coming out fast, sees soldiers pulling open the front THREE pickup trucks speed into the compound -- SPLA milit - skidding to a stop. Sam rushing over as soldiers help two YOUNG BOYS out of o trucks. Both are around 5 years old, injured and crying. third child is lifted out in a makeshift stretcher -- thi - 10 years old -- her broken body limp and bleeding profu mumbling something to herself in Arabic over-and-over aga

-- DOORS BANGING OPEN! -- CONTROLLED CHAOS as the childre hauled into this clinic -- Betty taking care of Alice -- off -- hooking her up to an IV as Sam moves to her bedsid little girl still mumbling quietly -- SAM
What is she saying? BETTY
She is asking what she did wrong? Sam taking Alice's hand in his... very slowly her beautif open and she sees him... and says something in Arabic... BETTY (CONT'D) (TRANSLATING)
She is asking if you are `The Preacher.' 60 SAM (NODDING)
Tell her she's gonna be ok. Betty translates and Alice smiles faintly... and now one other camp women comes over and Sam steps back so they ca
Sam coming out of the infirmary and finding Deng here wit the SPLA soldiers who brought the children. SAM
Where did they find em? DENG
Their village was hit out Adjumani. Off Sam, hearing this, we...

And we see Sam and Deng sitting outside the infirmary, ex been here all night waiting. And now the door opens and B out. She looks down at them and simply shakes her head... And we know Alice is dead. And it looks like a grenade has gone off inside Sam. And grabs an AK and gets up, seething, walks off... DENG
Sam...
... Sam walking fast through the compound... Deng followi DENG
Where are you going? SAM
Adjumani. DENG
Sam, please wait... SAM
I ain't waitin. You wanna see what waitin gets ya? Take a look in that buildin over there... Sam reaching the SUV and starting to gear up... 61
FADE UP the plaintive wail of an Acholi WAR SONG... haunt ethereal... and then a chorus of voices rising up... taki

Bombing down this rutted, red dirt road. The engine at fu Sam, Deng, Nineteen, Marco, and A.J. jammed into this tru in dead silence... AK47's bouncing between their knees... sound of the WAR SONG playing as we watch these men... a stillness on their faces... thinking of what men do just their own death.
We see two LRA VEHICLES approaching in the distance... a and a PICKUP TRUCK behind it...
Four CHILD SOLDIERS squatting in the flatbed of this truc AK47's. We recognize one of the boys as the younger broth opening scene -- WILLIAM.

With two ADULT REBELS in this Jeep as they drive down thi bombed-out vehicles... and in the distance we see the smo wreckage of a transport truck on the side of the road... smoke hanging over the road like a black curtain... block vision of the road ahead... ... and the Jeep punches into the black smoke followed by truck... and we're lost in the swirling haze for a moment coming out the other side... and this is what we see -- SAM -- standing in the middle of the road ahead of us sho RPG -- the ADULT REBELS see him just as -- WHOOOOSH! -- an RPG streaks right at us and DETONATES -- and the Jeep flips onto it's side --

THE PICKUP GRINDS TO A STOP! -- the driver slamming it in - accelerating back into the curtain of smoke -- trying t fuck out of there when -- BBrrraaaappp! .30 CALIBER MACHINEGUN STRAFE across the front hood --
-- and we see A.J. behind the .30 cal -- opening it up -- BBRAAAAAAPPP! -- BBRAAAAAPPP! -- blasting the engine comp the truck, trying to disable it -- 62

-- the pickup truck reversing out of the black smoke -- O CONTROL -- going off the road into a ditch -- WILLIAM and boys bailing out of the flatbed -- TWO ADULT REBELS pilin the cab -- scrambling for cover behind the truck.

Sam, Deng, A.J. and the others hustling through the smoke finding cover. From Sam's vantage point he sees rebels hi behind the disabled truck for cover -- shooting back -- a firefight -- the big .30 cal ROARING offscreen but the tr protecting the rebels -- no clear shot --

William and the other child soldiers here with two ADULT crouched behind the truck for cover -- the ADULT REBELS r fire, but the children aren't moving, scared shitless. William peers around the truck and sees Sam fifty yards a to the boys next to him... WILLIAM (ARABIC)
It's the white preacher! The other boys reacting, this means something to them. An of the ADULT REBEL turns to the children... ADULT REBEL
And he pops up and returns fire, but the boys don't move.
MARCO running through the smoke toward Sam. He hits the g starts to screw an RPG into his launcher... he wants to h transport truck, but Sam shakes his head, waves him off.. SAM
No shot! There are children behind the truck! Marco hears this, ditches the RPG and picks up his AK. SAM (CONT'D)

Cover me! Marco laying down suppression fire as Sam sprints across advancing on the transport truck -- firing his AK from th bullets zinging past him -- he dives behind a berm and fi next to Deng. Neither man says a word as they jam fresh m their AK's, gunfire erupting all around them. 63
The adult rebels continue fighting -- alternately popping behind the truck and returning fire. The ADULT REBEL real William and the other boys still aren't fighting -- ADULT REBEL
Fight you cowards!!! But William and the other boys don't move, and the Adult shooting until his mag clicks empty. He looks around and LAUNCHER on the ground, picks it up, arms it --
Sam and Deng behind the berm. Sam peers over just as GUNF him by inches. He drops back. DENG
Why don't you just go home? SAM
What? DENG
This is not your war. SAM
You leavin? Deng shakes his head -- SAM (CONT'D)
Well then, I ain't leavin neither... Sam chambers a round, pivots around the berm as --
-- the Adult Rebel stands up with the RPG -- fires! -- at instant William shoots him in the head -- he jerks -- WOO the missile launching at a bad angle as --
RPG streaking directly at him -- hitting the ground short

head_text.subj: AND OUR VISION EXPLODES TO WHITE

text: For a long beat... only silence... and then slowly the wh to fade... and we see Sam flat on his back... eyes blinki shell-shocked... staring up at blue sky... and then a sha over him... someone stepping into his POV... 64

it's William, hands held open in surrender, staring curio this strange white man laying in the dirt... and now Deng appear next to Sam and help him to his feet. And we see the battle is over. The remaining child soldie emerging from behind the LRA truck... laying down their w walking toward Sam... joining William... staring at this in front of them... ... William reaches into his pocket and... ... Deng and Marco REACT -- lifting their AK's -- "Don't move!" -- but the boy only pulls out a FADED PHOTOGRAPH.. he grabbed just before his capture... a picture of him an brother... standing next to each other smiling. WILLIAM (ARABIC)
Have you seen my brother?
80 children laying on the floor on reed mats, getting rea sleep. And we find William in mid-conversation with a you named Anthony. WILLIAM
... Where are you from? ANTHONY
Jabal. WILLIAM
Were you with the rebels? Anthony nods. William pulls out his photograph. WILLIAM (CONT'D)
Did you know my brother? He was called Christopher. Anthony studying the photograph... WILLIAM (CONT'D)
He has a funny left eye. It looks the other way sometimes. Do you remember him? ANTHONY
No. William folding up the photograph, getting up, moving to little boy a few feet away... kneeling next to him... and continues... WILLIAM
I am William. Were you with the rebels? 65
A soldier cuts off the generator and the compound goes bl
And we see Sam on his cot when the light goes out. He lea torches a small Kerosene lamp next to him.

The children on their mats in the dark now... quiet... a younger ones whimpering, starting to cry... the darkness too much... reminding them of past horrors... and then we FAINT VOICE in this dark room... singing quietly... an an African lullaby... and then other little voices joining i singing this song they all know... a song their mother's to them...
... Sam hearing the soft chorus drift across the compound finding comfort in it too... blowing out the lamp and lay the dark... listening to the children sing.

A SLOW DISSOLVE... life springing up in the camp... dayli breaking... a routine seen here... Betty, Rose and the ot women arriving at the orphanage... cooking fires being li soldiers drinking cups of strong coffee, warming themselv long night... ... and Sam coming out of his tukul carrying his duffle b discovering William curled up next to his door, sleeping the dirt... been there all night. William stirring awake, above him and scrambling to his feet. SAM
Mornin, buddy. William, no response. Just staring up at him. SAM (CONT'D)
Ain't you gonna say nuthin? William, nothing. SAM (CONT'D)
Ok then. And Sam walks across the compound followed by William a f behind... and he reaches Deng, Betty, Nineteen, and a few other volunteers waiting by the truck... 66 DENG (MEANING WILLIAM)
Looks like you've got yourself a bodyguard. SAM
Guess I do. Sam tosses his bag into the back, says goodbye to everyon SAM (CONT'D)
Take care of things while I'm gone, ok? DENG
I will, Preacher. They shake hands and Sam gets into the truck... and we se already here, sitting in the backseat. SAM
You can't come with me, buddy. DENG
(to William, Arabic) Get out of there. But William isn't moving... DENG (CONT'D) (ARABIC)
Come on! -- out! -- ... and finally Deng reaches in and grabs him... tries to out but he fights back... yelling as Deng drags him out o truck...

Sam turning around in his seat as we pull away from the c and he sees William still struggling in Deng's arms... an he breaks free and SPRINTS for the truck as it drives off he can... chasing Sam until he no longer can. CUT TO:
And we see two teens moving toward the sound of a crowd c inside the church, responsive, "Hallelujah!"... and then over it all...
In your actions you give service to the Lord... 67
Sam at the pulpit in mid-sermon. There is an air of Fire Brimstone to what we're watching here... electric... the congregation listening in rapt attention... SAM

... he's not interested in your good thoughts... your good intentions... he wants your hands... your backs... your sweat... your blood to pour into the foundation that will build up his kingdom! Ad-libbed SHOUTS and PRAISE... and now we see Lynn, Daisy and Paige in the congregation listening... as we go --

Lynn and Sam walking through the facility, and we see thi alive with activity. More than just a church, this is a c center. Lynn opening a door and we see a Volunteer here w little children running around this playroom... LYNN
We started daycare last month. Monday thru Friday from 8 to 2... Sundays after first worship for a few hours if anybody needs it. How you doin, Sue? VOLUNTEER
Good. Hey Pastor. SAM

Sue. Lynn pulling the door closed and they continue... moving of stairs to the basement where we see children and paren of them playing ping-pong and air hockey... others in a c rehearsing for a Christmas play... SAM (CONT'D)
Been thinkin we need to put up a playground. Swings. Some things the kids can climb on. LYNN
We can't build anymore. Not for awhile. SAM
You said Sundays has been full. LYNN
Turn outs been good, but that don't mean people is givin money. (MORE) 68 LYNN (CONT'D)
Economy is in trouble, construction business is slow. Times is tight. SAM
Be good for them kids, Lynn. LYNN
They got the playground over in Cairnbrook. And they can play at the school on weekends if they want Sam turning to her -- SAM
Not talking bout here. Talkin about the orphange. Lynn catching up to him now, realizing his head is still Africa.
Sam working on his Harley. Donnie entering in the b.g. DONNIE
What'cha workin on, buddy? SAM
Trouble with the push rods I think. She's runnin kinda rough. DONNIE
Shoulda kept that mild in there `stead a buildin up a hot rod. Let's see whatcha got here... Donnie moving next to him, working on the bike... DONNIE (CONT'D)
... never had these problems when we was runnin solid lifters, huh? SAM
Used to fix them old shovelheads on the side of the road with a buckknife and a wire hanger. DONNIE
Remember that year we went to the Freakers Ball? Sam smiling... SAM
I think that old `78 broke down five times on that trip. 69 DONNIE
Sounds about right. Shoot, we had more fun tryin to get there than when we finally did. Sam and Donnie share a laugh. DONNIE (CONT'D)
Can I talk to you about somethin? SAM
Yep. DONNIE
I'm glad I'm walkin with the Lord and all, but sometimes I ain't sure I'm gonna be able to do what he wants me to do. SAM
The Lord don't ask for nuthin you can't deliver, buddy. And yer one tough ole boy. DONNIE
Sometimes I ain't so sure how tough I am. And we see in Donnie's eyes just how troubled he is. SAM
Why don't we pray together then... And they both take a knee, bowing their heads as Sam cont SAM (CONT'D)

Our gracious Heavenly Father, bless us with the strength to carry on in your name. And grant us, in our darkest hours, the understandin that you are always by our side. And we leave these two men, their heads bowed in quiet su next to this Harley, praying for strength.
Four or five gleaming sedans on this showroom floor. And sitting across from BILL WALLACE, late 40's, gold Rolex. BILL
... from what I heard, you built yourself one helluva church over there in Central City. 70 SAM
Still got a ways to go, but we're gettin there. You should come on by one of these Sundays, bring the family. BILL
That's nice of you, but we're at Calvary now. Bit more our speed over there I think. Sam, getting down to business... SAM
Reverand Carlton gives a mean sermon, puts me to shame. Anyway Bill, I'm here cause I wanna talk to you about what we're doin over there in Africa. BILL
Course I know about what you're doin. Helluva thing helpin out those kids, Sam. SAM

Thank you, but I'm gonna be straight with ya. We're hurtin for money... If we had a little bit more support from people like yourself sure would help things run a lot smoother over there. Bill feeling the rub, shaking his head... BILL
Sam, look, everybody is feelin the pinch around here. SAM
I hear that, but you gotta understand that them kids over there got nuthin. I mean nuthin, Bill, and I'm not asking for much. BILL
How much you lookin for? SAM
Five thousand dollars. BILL
Jesus Christ, Sam! Five thousand dollars? SAM
That keeps them doors open for another six months. 71 BILL

People are losin their jobs left and right round here. Tough to be askin for five thousand dollars for a buncha African children half-way around the world. Sam shifting, not giving up, coming at him another way... SAM

You're right. We got problems right here. But with that kinda money we could feed them kids, house them kids. Bill staring at him, saying nothing, on the spot. Sam hop somehow he's reached this man. And finally Bill stands up BILL
Alright, tell you what, lemme see what I can do. Sam feeling this victory, flashing a smile, shaking Bill' SAM
Ok. BILL
Why don't you and the family come over to the house next Sunday. We're havin a little barbeque, ok? SAM
Sounds good.

Upscale French provincial in suburban Johnstown. A "barbe underway. 15 couples here with their kids and a handful o in white-tie offering champagne and hors d'oeuvres to the DOOR BELL RINGING -- and we see a perky woman in her late coming through the crowd, blonde hair from a bottle, acce the hilt, holding a glass of white wine. SHANNON WALLACE. the door to find Sam, Lynn, and Paige standing in the doo SHANNON
Well, come on in... And they enter... Lynn smiling awkwardly, dressed in the dress we saw her in previously... her only dress... and S around this enormous room... SHANNON (CONT'D)
Ya'll must be the Childers. Welcome. I'm Shannon, Bill's ball-n-chain. 72
Smiling, a joke she loves... LYNN
I'm Lynn, this here is Sam, our daughter Paige. SHANNON
Good to meet you.
There he is! Everybody turning to see the car dealer coming through th smiling, a little drunk. AD-LIBBED introductions and then BILL

Glad ya'll could make it. Get on in here and meet some people... Bill ushering them deeper into the house... quick intros guests as they pass... Sam, Lynn, and Paige taking it all starting to sense the dimensions of this massive house... waiters in their pressed jackets offering them food... th extravagance... like nothing they've ever seen... ... Bill pulling Sam off from the crowd so it's just the them... taking an envelope from his jacket and handing it BILL (CONT'D)
This is a little somethin for the kids, ok? What we were talking about. SAM
Thank you, Bill. BILL
Forget it. Now c'mon, can I get ya a mojito or somethin?

Sam coming into this bathroom and locking the door... tak envelope out of his pocket and tearing it open... pulling personal check -- CLOSE UP to see it's in the amount of $ HOLD ON Sam face, and it's disgust we see in his eyes.
Front door opening fast and Lynn and Paige coming out, fo Sam, pushing them along... LYNN
Sam... 73 PAIGE
Why we leavin so soon? Shannon appearing in the doorway in the b.g., calling aft SHANNON
Everything alright?... Lynn turning to respond, but Sam keeps her moving forward driveway, past the line of parked BMW's and Mercedes to t at the curb... SAM
Get in the car. LYNN
What's wrong? As they load into the truck... SAM
Sonuvabitch is cryin pour-mouth to me and he's livin in the damn Taj Mahal... LYNN
Sam... SAM

I asked him for five-thousand dollars to feed a buncha motherless babies and you know what he gave me? (taking out the check, wadding it up) Hundred and fifty bucks. That's it. Handed it to me like it was gold bouillon! Sonuvabitch spent more than that on salsa for his party.
-- Sam coming into the house, enraged, followed by Lynn. his gun cabinet, grabs a hidden key, unlocks it... LYNN
What are you doin? SAM
I've had it with these people and all their bullshit about wantin to help... And he starts pulling out weapons... shotguns and assault stuffing them into an oversize gun bag... LYNN
Sam Childers... 74
Lynn reaching for him and he grabs her wrist... tightly.. at her with dark eyes. A flash of the "old" Sam Childers he says... SAM
Stay outta my way. And for the first time in years this woman is scared. He her wrist and continues to fill the bag -- and we go --
Sam coming out followed by the Shop Owner... SHOP OWNER
... I'm sorry, twenty-five hundred is the best I can do for them gun. REVERSE to see Lynn's car parked at the curb, Sam pointin SAM
Throw in the car for five. The Shop Owner considering, as we go...
Windy, pissing rain. And we see Sam walking up this rural hands in his pockets, head down... the only human for mil trudging through this shitstorm completely alone. CUT TO:

And we see Sam with a group of men working in the swelter laying brick... adding another room to the children's dor ... and he squints into the distance, sees a cloud of dus horizon, cars coming closer.
Seven or eight heavily armed vehicles coming through the 20 or 30 SPLA soldiers guarding a black SUBURBAN in the m this motorcade. Nineteen waving his hand, yelling as the NINETEEN (ARABIC)
It's Garang! -- It's Garang! -- Palpable excitement ripples through the compound... Sam's grabbing their weapons and forming a ragged line near the as it stops... 75

... the back door to the Suburban opens and a black man, shirtsleeves and slacks, steps out. The same man we saw g fiery speech on the little outdoor TV in Nimule earlier - GARANG. Sam turns to Deng -- SAM
Who's this guy? DENG
That's our leader. SAM
John Garang? Deng nods as we go...
Sam and Garang walking through the middle of camp, traile squad of SPLA bodyguards and camp children... GARANG
They call you Preacher. Is this what I should call you? SAM
Sam is fine. GARANG
I hear what you have done for the SPLA and I am grateful. SAM
We can thank God for his blessins. GARANG
Yes, we can. How many children do you look after, Sam? SAM

Couple hundred with us here. Feed another thousand a day from nearby villages. Anyone who shows up hungry gets a meal. And they continue through the camp. A few of the children to Garang, touching the cuff of his shirt, then sprinting GARANG
What you are doing is noble, but too dangerous. I must advise you to stop risking your life in our struggle. 76 SAM
Until someone starts fightin for these children, I'm the one that's gonna do it. GARANG
You are stubborn, aren't you? SAM
As a mule. Garang smiling, an instant affinity for this man. GARANG
You and I come from very different worlds, but we are not so dissimilar. And another child runs up to Garang, touching him, and th away giggling... GARANG (CONT'D)

I founded the SPLA in order to fight for the future of Sudan because nobody else would. We fight for freedom from the government in Khartoum, for the right to vote, and for the right to worship any god one may choose. More children running up... Garang touching their heads.. GARANG (CONT'D)
But most important to me is our struggle for the children. Their laughter has been lost to this country for far too long. (BEAT)
There are Peace Talks scheduled for the end of August in Naivashu. I'd like you to come as my guest. SAM
Talkin bout peace in a room somewhere is a waste of time. You gotta go out and make it. GARANG

You are correct, but we must fight them at every level. Part of my battle is waged in those rooms. We must talk of peace, but keep our rifles ready for war. Sam turning to him, coming to an understanding here. Real both of them are warriors in the same fight. GARANG (CONT'D)
Maybe together you and I can make Sudan free once again. 77
And now we see they have arrived at the brick chapel in t of the compound. Garang turning to him, eyes suddenly bec dark... GARANG (CONT'D)
There is a cost for freedom, Sam. A price for the future of these people. Some pay with their lives, others pay in different ways. (BEAT)
My only hope is that your cost is not too great. AND SUDDENLY WE'RE SOMEPLACE FAR AWAY... ANOTHER WORLD...

head_text.subj: SILHOUETTES OF ANIMALS DANCING ON A DARK CEILING... PROJE

text: Donnie tucking Paige into bed, making it up as he goes, c of his depth here but wanting to do it right. DONNIE
You say prayers or somethin? PAIGE
Already did. DONNIE
Ok then, sweet dreams. PAIGE
Ain't you gonna read me a book? DONNIE
Ahh, Paige, you know I don't read so good. PAIGE
Then let's play a game. DONNIE
Ok. PAIGE
I'm thinkin of a dog. DONNIE
What about it? PAIGE
Never mind, Donnie. DONNIE
Ok. 78 PAIGE
Dad usually kisses me on the forehead before he leaves. You can do that. DONNIE
Sure I can. And Donnie does just that, bends down and kisses Paige on head... DONNIE (CONT'D)
Sweet dreams. And now we see Lynn in the hallway having just witnessed through the cracked door, keenly feeling Sam absence in t
And we see Sam, Betty and Rose leading a group of childre hands covering their eyes so they can't see, into a clear one of the dorms. SAM
Keep em closed! A little bit more! BETTY (ARABIC)
Keep your eyes closed. ROSE
(stern, Arabic) Michael! Cover your eyes! No peeking! SAM

head_text.subj: WHITE LETTERS ON A BLACK SCREEN THAT READ --

text: "To this day, Sam Childers fights for the children of Sud Northern Uganda." THE END 120 LEGENDS:

Joseph Kony and his Lord's Resistance Army continue their terror in Sudan and Northern Uganda. Amnesty International estimates that Kony and the LRA are responsible for over 400,000 murders and more than 40,000 abductions. These children are tortured, raped, sold into slavery, and forced to take part in ritualized killing by commanders. The Islamic Government of Sudan continues to provide weap safe haven to Kony and the LRA as part of a deal to wage against the predominately Christian South. Without pressure from the United States, this support wil and more innocent children will be slaughtered. Now you know. 121
